channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Afghanistan conflict: Taliban push into Kabul as president flees
item.description: The militants are close to taking total control now that US-led forces have all but withdrawn.

item.title: Taliban spokesman tells BBC they are 'awaiting a peaceful transfer of power'
item.description: The BBC's Yalda Hakim was contacted by a spokesperson for the Taliban, Suhail Shaheen, live on air.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Rescuers search for survivors as death toll climbs to 700
item.description: More than 700 people are known to have died after a powerful earthquake hit the nation on Saturday.

item.title: Independence Day: Key takeaways from PM Modi's speech
item.description: India is celebrating 75 years of independence as it continues to battle coronavirus.

item.title: Japan rain: Nearly two million residents told to seek shelter
item.description: Some provinces are under evacuation alerts as experts warn of "unprecedented" rainfall.

item.title: Germany football legend Muller dies aged 75
item.description: Bayern Munich and Germany legend Gerd Muller dies at the age of 75.

item.title: Zambia election: President claims vote was not free and fair
item.description: Early results show Edgar Lungu, who is seeking a second term, trailing rival Hakainde Hichilema.

item.title: Sri Lankan teenager builds solar-powered tuk-tuk from scraps
item.description: Piranawan, 15, from Sri Lanka spent eight months of his Covid lockdown making his eco-friendly vehicle.

item.title: Australia: New South Wales 'in worst ever Covid situation'
item.description: While case numbers are relatively low, the Australian state's premier has warned of a Covid surge.

item.title: Polish law on property stolen by Nazis angers Israel
item.description: A new law will make it harder for people to recover property lost in World War Two.

item.title: Rahul Gandhi: Twitter restores Congress party member accounts
item.description: Rahul Gandhi and opposition allies had been suspended for sharing photos of a rape victim's parents.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.

item.title: Who is TikTok’s masked vigilante?
item.description: Think you’re safe being an anonymous TikTok troll or cyber bully? Meet your worst nightmare.

item.title: 'My night in notorious Nazi collaborator Quisling's cabin'
item.description: When Ben McPherson realised he could rent Vidkun Quisling's cabin, it struck him as weird. His Norwegian wife disagreed.

item.title: 'This was a race and we lost': How US doctors really feel about Covid surge
item.description: Healthcare workers react to the growing rise of Covid patients in US hospitals despite vaccines.

item.title: Ethiopia: What do we know about aid going into Tigray?
item.description: Who's preventing desperately needed aid supplies reaching Ethiopia's Tigray region?

item.title: Myanmar: The woman who jumped to her death while fleeing police
item.description: Wai Wai Myint was among five people who jumped out of a building while fleeing a police raid in Myanmar.

item.title: Afghans living under Taliban lament loss of freedoms
item.description: Afghans in Taliban-controlled provinces describe life under its fundamentalist Islamist rule.

item.title: Climate change: Does Germany produce double the UK's carbon emissions?
item.description: MP John Redwood claims that, on carbon emissions, Germany "puts out twice as much as we do". Is he right?

item.title: Haiti struck by deadly 7.2-magnitude earthquake
item.description: A powerful earthquake has struck the Caribbean nation of Haiti, killing at least 304 people.

item.title: ICYMI: Little Amal the walking refugee puppet and Perseid meteor shower
item.description: We also travel back to the Ice Age and to Sao Paulo's tallest building in this week's round-up.

item.title: Afghanistan: Journalist Anisa Shaheed refuses to give in to Taliban
item.description: Anisa Shaheed fears women's freedoms will be curbed again if the Taliban come to power.

item.title: Afghanistan in serious danger - President Ghani
item.description: Ashraf Ghani addresses the nation as the Taliban reportedly close in on the Afghan capital, Kabul.

item.title: Afghanistan: Desperation as thousands flee the Taliban
item.description: Yogita Limaye reports from a camp in Kabul where thousands who have been displaced by violence seek refuge.
